basics.name: Xuanfei Ren
basics.summary: PhD student in Computer Science at University of Wisconsin-Madison, advised by Prof. Tengyang Xie. Research interests in reinforcement learning theory, AI agents, and LLM post-training.

education.institution: University of Science and Technology of China (USTC)
education.area: Mathematics, specialization in Probability and Statistics

publications.summary: Joint work with Tianyuan Jin and Pan Xu. Accepted to the 41st International Conference on Machine Learning.
publications.authors: Xuanfei Ren, Tianyuan Jin, Pan Xu

research_experience.title: Heuristic Exploration for Self-Improving Agentic Systems
research_experience.collaborators: Dr. Ching-An Cheng (Microsoft Research) and Prof. Tengyang Xie
description: Established a handcrafted baseline agent for the benchmark and defined reproducible evaluation metrics.
Integrated Microsoft's Trace framework to automate structured prompt tuning and decision-logic optimization.
Designed and implement novel meta search algorithms that exploit Trace to enhance the optimization process.

research_experience.title: Offline Alignment for Language Models
description: Performed an in-depth literature review on offline reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms.
Applied offline RL algorithms to enhance alignment in large language models (LLMs).

research_experience.title: Offline Reinforcement Learning and Policy Evaluation Theory
description: Developed theoretical insights into value-based reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms.
Theoretically analyzed estimation and approximation errors across various policy evaluation methods.
Designed and conducted experiments to validate theoretical predictions.

research_experience.title: Optimal Batched Linear Bandits
research_experience.advisor: Prof. Pan Xu (Department of Computer Science, Duke University)
description: Devised an algorithm striving for asymptotic and non-asymptotic optimality in the linear bandits setting, an achievement previously unattained.
Adapted the algorithm into a batched version with provable least batch complexity, extending applicability to common real-world problems.
Confirmed the algorithm's superiority over existing baseline methods through rigorous experimentation, showcasing its practical efficacy in linear bandits problems.
